urn:contentItem:66C2-K2D1-JBMY-H1Y6-00000-00Self-compassion and Shame Among Rape Survivors2025-11-15T08:21:42Z2025-11-15T08:21:42ZLexisNexisPg. NaN-NaNSelf-compassion and Shame Among Rape Survivors

The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

ORCID iDsPrachi H. Bhuptani https://orcid.org/0000-0003-4316-0947Terri L. Messman https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7676-5374

L.B. KleinElizabeth A. MoschellaElise LopezPrachi H. BhuptaniTerri L. MessmanABSTRACT

Women are at increased risk for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and depression associated with rape, and shame plays a vital role in the development and maintenance of PTSD and depression. Thus, there is a need to identify factors that may decrease shame among female survivors of adult rape. Self-compassion may be one such factor. The present study used path analysis in MPlus version 7.3 to examine the indirect effect of self-compassion on PTSD and depression via rape-related shame. We hypothesized that higher levels of self-compassion would be associated with lower levels of rape-related shame, which in turn would be associated with lower levels of PTSD and depression. College women (N = 305) who reported experiencing rape completed anonymous online surveys assessing rape, self-compassion, rape-related shame, PTSD, and depression. Consistent with our hypothesis, results indicated that self-compassion was negatively associated with assault-related shame, which in turn was positively associated with PTSD and depression. There was also a significant indirect effect of self-compassion on PTSD and depression via rape-related shame. Further, rape-related shame fully explained the relation between self-compassion and PTSD. Findings suggest that self-compassion may be an appropriate target to reduce rape-related shame and may subsequently facilitate reductions in PTSD and depression symptoms.

FULL TEXT

Rape, a common form of trauma experienced by women in the United States (Breiding et al., 2015), is associated with numerous adverse outcomes (Dworkin et al., 2017). Two especially common outcomes of experiencing rape are post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and depression. A review on the prevalence of mental health disorders among sexual assault survivors indicated that over half of survivors develop PTSD and Major Depressive Disorder (Campbell et al., 2009). Sexual assault survivors are more vulnerable to PTSD and depression compared to survivors of other types of trauma and individuals who did not experience trauma (Kelley et al., 2009; Zinzow et al., 2010, 2012). Shame may explain these high rates of distress among sexual assault survivors (Scheff, 2003, p. 239; Wilson et al., 2006). Given the prominent role of shame in the development and maintenance of PTSD and depression among sexual assault survivors (Feiring et al., 1998), it is important to identify factors that are associated with shame. One such factor could be self-compassion. The purpose of this study is to examine whether self-compassion is associated with lower levels of PTSD and depression symptoms via lower levels of rape-related shame in a sample of women who experienced rape. Before we investigate these relations, we must first understand what shame is and why it is relevant to rape survivors.

The Relevance of Shame

Shame is known to be a ubiquitous response to sexual assault (Vidal & Petrak, 2007). Lewis (1987, pp. 15-18) defined shame as “one’s own vicarious experience of the other’s scorn…shame may also be played out as an internal colloquy, in which the whole self is condemned.” From this definition, shame is viewed as an intensely aversive emotion where the whole self is seen as flawed and debased and therefore, unworthy of acceptance and belonging (Brown, 2006). Shame is both a self-conscious and a social emotion (Hareli & Parkinson, 2008), experienced in the context of relationships with other individuals, institutions, and broader societal norms. More specifically, shame evolves within a person when they anticipate, infer, or experience negative judgement and rejection from other individuals, institutions, and/or anticipate judgment based upon societal norms. These negative introjects then lead to self-rejection and self-judgement. This social and internalized nature of shame drives its prominence for sexual assault survivors.

Recovery from sexual assault is embedded in a multilevel context where sexual victimization is a highly stigmatized experience (Kennedy & Prock, 2018). Societal beliefs and rape myths that hold the survivors responsible, either completely or in part, for the assault feed into the stigmatized nature of sexual assault (Edwards et al., 2011; Moor & Farchi, 2011). Survivors are immersed in this context before, during, and after the assault. These blaming messages are communicated to them through media representations, dominant narratives, and stereotypes. They are also directly communicated to survivors after the assault in the form of unsupportive responses to assault disclosure (Ahrens, 2006; Ahrens et al., 2010). As a result of being embedded in this blaming cultural context, survivors internalize stigma and blame, and begin blaming themselves for the violence inflicted upon then. This internalized stigma and blame feeds into shame, which in turn leads to PTSD and depression (Bhuptani & Messman-Moore, 2019). As a result of elevated shame, sexual assault survivors may engage in self-criticism ( Harman & Lee, 2010), start isolating themselves from their sources of support or feel abandoned (Jacques-Tiura et al., 2010), engage in rumination (Conway et al., 2004), or feel overwhelmed by their emotional pain, all of which are pathways to distress.

The Relevance of Self-compassion

Kristen Neff (2003b, p. 22), a pioneer in investigating self-compassion, defines it as “an open-hearted way of relating to the negative aspects of oneself and one’s experience that enables greater emotional resilience and psychological well-being.” In other words, it is a caring and compassionate stance that one takes toward the self, especially during difficult times. It is conceptualized as a trait entailing three opposite facets: self-kindness versus self-criticism, common humanity versus isolation, and mindfulness versus overidentification (Neff, 2003a). Self-kindness involves the tendency to be caring and understanding in the context of difficulties, in contrast to condemning or criticizing oneself. Common humanity reflects the ability to recognize our experiences and struggles as an inherently universal aspect of the human experience, in contrast to feeling isolated upon perceiving one’s struggles as unusual or uncommon. Finally, mindfulness is one aspect of self-compassion which involves being aware of one’s negative thoughts and emotions without being consumed by them.

Growing evidence suggests that self-compassion is positively related to well-being and adaptive psychological functioning. Higher levels of self-compassion are associated with greater life satisfaction, optimism, and well-being (Barnard & Curry, 2011; Neff, 2012). In contrast, lower levels of self-compassion are associated with higher levels of pessimistic thinking, rumination, and fear of failure. Further, self-compassion has shown to be negatively related to more severe psychopathology such as depression and anxiety in both nonclinical and clinical samples (Krieger et al., 2013; Neff, 2003a). The most robust findings come from a meta-analysis that reported moderate overall effect sizes for the relation between self-compassion and depressive symptoms (r = –.52) and anxiety symptoms (r = –.51; MacBeth & Gumley, 2012).

In addition to its relation with depression, self-compassion has also been linked to PTSD symptoms among trauma-exposed individuals. A cross-sectional study with a community sample found that self-compassion was associated with overall PTSD severity and individual symptoms (re-experiencing, hyperarousal, avoidance, and dysphoria; Maheux & Price, 2015) as well as mediated the relation between social support and PTSD (and depression) symptoms (Maheux & Price, 2016). These findings are corroborated by evidence from longitudinal research that supports the role of self-compassion in PTSD. A study with youth exposed to a potentially traumatic forest fire found that higher self-compassion at one-month postexposure predicted fewer PTSD and depression symptoms at three- and six-month postexposure (Zeller et al., 2015). In a study with combat veterans, low self-compassion predicted higher PTSD severity over 12 months, even after controlling for combat exposure and baseline PTSD severity, emphasizing the longstanding negative impact of low self-compassion (Hiraoka et al., 2015). Along this vein, two different pilot studies have tested the effectiveness of self-compassion interventions for treating PTSD among combat veterans. Both studies found that these interventions led to reductions in PTSD (Kearney et al., 2013) and depression symptoms (Serpa et al., 2020) over 8-12-week period.

Other studies provide a more nuanced picture of the relation between self-compassion and PTSD symptoms. These two cross-sectional studies used college samples. One study found that self-compassion was associated with only the avoidance symptom cluster of PTSD, and not with other symptom clusters (Thompson & Waltz, 2008). Another study found that self-compassion was not associated with individual PTSD symptom clusters after controlling for psychological inflexibility (Seligowski et al., 2015). Overall, this body of evidence suggests that higher levels of self-compassion are associated with lower levels of PTSD and depression symptoms among trauma-exposed individuals. However, it is important to note that the aforementioned studies which investigated correlates of self-compassion (Seligowski et al., 2015) as well as effectiveness of self-compassion interventions (Kearney et al., 2013), did not examine how such factors may be related to rape. Moreover, previous studies do not identify mechanisms that explain how self-compassion can ameliorate distress. One potential mechanism may be shame.

The Impact of Self-compassion on Shame

Self-compassion is highly relevant to rape and sexual assault survivors for two main reasons: its overlap with common processes that occur during assault recovery (e.g., isolation) and its impact on shame. Each of the three opposite components of self-compassion can mitigate existing feelings of shame among rape survivors. The first component of self-compassion is self-kindness (vs. self-criticism). Given that high levels of self-criticism are directly linked to the process of internal shaming (Gilbert, 2005, 2007), self-kindness may directly ameliorate shame by offering care and understanding toward the self. This ability to be kind, warm, and understanding toward oneself, especially in the context of perceived failure, can lead to significant reductions in shame (Gilbert & Procter, 2006). The second component of self-compassion is common humanity (vs. isolation), which involves adopting a broader, contextual view of one’s struggles and negative experiences within the realm of universal human experience. People who experience or acknowledge common humanity can imagine that many other people would have made similar behavioral choices and that this negative event could have happened to anyone when faced with negative events (Terry & Leary, 2011). This element of self-compassion can help reduce feelings of shame by allowing individuals to focus less on how they were uniquely to blame for what happened to them. The final element of self-compassion is mindfulness (vs. overidentification), which is negatively associated with shame (Goldsmith et al., 2014a). Mindfulness reduces shame by enabling trauma survivors to be open to negative affect and experiences without self-judgment (Follette et al., 2006).

Given that individual components of self-compassion are theoretically linked with shame, preliminary research has started documenting associations between self-compassion and shame among various populations. Most of this research focuses on women with eating disorders, which indicates self-compassion is negatively associated with shame in this population (Ferreira et al., 2013, 2014). Only three studies have examined this association beyond bivariate levels. A treatment study found that individuals who demonstrated greater increases in their level of self-compassion also reported faster decreases in their feelings of shame over 12 weeks, even when controlling for their early change in eating disorder symptoms (Kelly et al., 2014). In another study, shame mediated the relation between self-compassion and psychosocial outcomes among individuals with HIV (Williams et al., 2019). The remaining study found that self-compassion and shame serially mediated the relation between childhood maltreatment and depression such that childhood maltreatment was associated with lower self-compassion, which was associated with higher shame (Ross et al., 2019). These high levels of shame were associated with higher levels of depressive symptoms. Only one study (Ross et al., 2019) to our knowledge has examined the relation between self-compassion and shame among trauma-exposed individuals. Given how these constructs play an important role in recovery from rape (Follette et al., 2006), it would seem germane to empirically investigate the relevance of this construct among survivors of rape.

Present Study

Survivors of rape and sexual assault experience higher rates of distress compared to survivors of other types of trauma (Zinzow et al., 2010, 2012). Shame is one factor that explains these high rates of distress (Amstadter & Vernon, 2008; Feiring et al., 1998). Additionally, self-compassion and shame are negatively associated with one another (e.g., Ferreira et al., 2014), and shame mediates the relation between self-compassion and psychosocial outcomes (Williams et al., 2019). Further, self-compassion interventionsare effective for reducing PTSD and depression symptoms among trauma-exposed individuals (Kearney et al., 2013). However, the role of self-compassion and its relation to shame among rape survivors has not been examined. Given this significant gap in literature, the aim of this study was to examine the indirect relation of self-compassion to depressive and PTSD symptoms through rape-related shame among women who had experienced rape. We hypothesized that high levels of self-compassion would be associated with low levels of rape-related shame, which in turn would be associated with lower levels of PTSD and depression symptoms.

MethodParticipants

The initial sample consisted of 1,479 female undergraduates at a midsized public university in the Midwestern United States, participating in a study examining shame responses amongst those who have experienced trauma. The final sample included only women who reported an experience of rape after the age of 14, 20.6% (n = 305) of the overall sample. Participants ranged in age from 18 to 22 years (M = 18.84, SD = .95). The majority of participants self-identified as White (91.5%), with 3.9% identifying as Asian, 3.6% identifying as Black, 2% as Biracial (2%), 1% as Native American, 1% as Pacific Islander, and 1% as another racial/ethnic background (1%). Additionally, a small portion of the sample (5.6%) identified as Latina/Hispanic. The majority were from upper-middle class households based upon reported family household incomes.

Procedures

Participants were recruited from a research participant pool (for Introduction to Psychology), and earned research credit for study completion. Informed consent was obtained from all participants included in the study. All participants met in the laboratory for informed consent/study instructions, but completed the online surveys outside the laboratory. No adverse effects from participating in the study were reported.

Measures

Rape and related variables. The modified Sexual Experiences Survey (SES) (Messman-Moore & Long, 2000; Messman-Moore et al., 2010) was used to assess rape after age 14. The measure includes a series of yes/no questions assessing specific types of attempted and completed unwanted sexual activities (ranging from kissing to fondling to penetration). For each unwanted activity, follow-up questions assessed the frequency and methods of coercion involved. Rape was defined as completed oral-genital contact or vaginal/anal penetration due to the inability to consent because of substance impairment (alcohol or drugs) or the use or threat of use of physical force

If a participant reported an unwanted sexual act, she was directed to answer additional follow-up questions about her most distressing experience. Additional details regarding the most distressing unwanted sexual experience were collected, including: type of unwanted sexual act(s), method of coercion used (e.g., force, threats of force), identity of the perpetrator (e.g., acquaintance, romantic partner, etc.), time since assault, and level of intoxication/impairment of the survivor. This information was utilized to identify experiences of rape as defined above.

Self-compassion. Self-compassion was assessed with the Self-Compassion Scale (Neff, 2003a), a 26-item questionnaire with six subscales which assesses positive (self-kindness, common humanity, and mindfulness) and negative self-compassion facets (self-judgment, isolation, and over-identification). Example items include “I try to be loving towards myself when I’m feeling emotional pain,” (self-kindness) or “When I’m feeling down I tend to obsess and fixate on everything that’s wrong” (overidentification). Response options on Likert scale range from 1 (almost never) to 5 (almost always). Items in the negative subscale scores were reverse scored. Item responses were summed and a mean score was calculated. Higher mean scores indicated higher levels of self-compassion. The SCS has good reliability and validity (Neff, 2003a). In the current sample, internal consistency for total scale was good (α = .90).

Rape-related shame. Questions assessing rape-related shame was asked in relation to the most distressing rape experience. The Trauma-Related Shame Inventory (Øktedalen et al., 2014) was used to assess rape-related shame. It is a 24-item self-report questionnaire where participants respond on a 4-point Likert scale, ranging from 1 (not true of me) to 4 (completely true of me). An example item on this scale is “If others knew what happened to me, they would view me as inferior.” Item responses were added to obtain a total score and higher total scores indicated greater levels of shame. The scale demonstrated excellent internal consistency in the current sample (α = .97).

Psychological distress. The PTSD Checklist for DSM-5 (PCL-5; Weathers et al., 2013) was used to assess PTSD symptoms in the past month. The PCL-5 is a 22-item self-report measure where participants respond on a 5-point Likert scale (0 = “not at all” to 4 = “extremely”). The depression subscale from the Depression, Anxiety and Stress Scale (DASS-21; Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995) was used to assess depression symptoms in the past week. The DASS-21 is a 7-item self-report measure where participant respond on a 4-point Likert scale (0 = “did not apply to me at all” to 3 = “applied to me very much or most of the time”). Higher scores on both measures indicate higher levels of distress. Internal reliability for both the PCL-5 (α = .95) and the DASS-21 depression subscale (α = .91) were good.

Data Analysis Plan

Data were examined for normality, completeness, and the presence of outliers or impossible values. Bivariate correlations were computed to examine general patterns of association and identify covariates. Path analysis using the Maximum Likelihood estimation method in MPlus version 7.3 tested one mediation model. Given the overlap between the distinct forms of psychological distress, error variances for the two dependent variables (depression and PTSD symptoms) were correlated. We tested the hypothesized indirect effect of self-compassion on PTSD and depression symptoms via rape-related shame, in addition to focusing on individual pathways, consistent with current recommendations (Hayes, 2013). Specifically, we tested the overall indirect effect for the model (i.e., self-compassion ↓ rape-related shame ↓ PTSD [and depression symptoms]) and used bootstrapping techniques to construct confidence intervals around the indirect effects (Hayes, 2013; Preacher & Hayes, 2004; Figure 1).

ResultsSkewness, Kurtosis, and Missing Data

The skewness and kurtosis of continuous variables were examined. All continuous variables were normally distributed and had a skewness value less than the absolute value of 2 (–.12 to 1.58) and a kurtosis value less than the absolute value of 2 (.08 to 1.97). Missing Value Analysis (MVA) in SPSS revealed values ranging from 1% to 3.6% across key study variables (i.e., self-compassion subscales, depression, etc.). Little’s MCAR test indicated data were not significantly different from the missing completely at random pattern, χ2 = 1218.52, df = 1,228, p = .57 (Little, 1988). Given this, single imputation using the Expectation Maximization algorithm was used following current guidelines for managing less than 8% item-level missing data (Widaman, 2006).

There was considerable variability in the timing of the index rape, ranging from less than one month ago (n = 23) to more than five years ago (n = 6). The modal timing of the index rape was between one to two years ago. Most women were raped by a known perpetrator (n = 265, 86.9%). Over half of the perpetrators (51.8%, n = 158) were known to participants in a romantic context (e.g., current or past romantic partner, casual date) or other sexual encounter (e.g., a new partner outside an established romantic relationship), and 35.1% of perpetrators (n = 105) were known to participants in a nonromantic context (e.g., friend, classmate, coworker, boss, acquaintance). Approximately one third (29.4% n = 91) of the women reported the perpetrator used threats or physical force (or a weapon) during the rape, 49.8% (n = 152) reported substance-related coercion, and the rest (20.3%, n = 62) reported the presence of both threat or force and substance-related coercion during the rape. Nearly half of the participants (n = 145, 47.5%) endorsed elevated depressive symptoms on the DASS-21 (i.e., scores ≥10, classified as mild through extremely severe; Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995). Although there is no definitive cutoff score for the PCL-5 (as indicative of a PTSD diagnosis), the U.S. Department of Veteran Affairs (2015) suggests a cutoff score of 31 until further psychometric data are available. Nearly one-quarter of the women (n = 70, 23%) met this cutoff criterion.

Path Analysis

Model fit statistics of the parallel mediation model (Figure 1) suggested that model fit was good. The chi-square was nonsignificant, χ² (2, N = 305) = 5.33, p = .07. Other indices also indicated a good fit, CFI = .99, TLI = .95, SRMR = .04, and RMSEA = .07. Next, we will discuss individual pathways and then examine the total, direct, and indirect effects.

Figure 1.Mediation model examining the relation of self-compassion on PTSD and depression symptoms through rape-related shame.

A mediation model, estimated with 10,000 bootstrap samples, was tested to examine the indirect effect of self-compassion on PTSD and depression symptoms via rape-related shame (Figure 1). Given that both PTSD and depression are distinct forms of psychological distress that share overlap, the error variances of both variables were correlated with each other. When examining individual pathways, self-compassion was negatively associated with rape-related shame such that higher levels of self-compassion were related with lower levels of rape-related shame. Rape-related shame, in turn, was positively associated with both PTSD symptoms and depression symptoms, over and above self-compassion, such that lower rape-related shame was related to lower levels of PTSD and depression symptoms.

The total effects of self-compassion on PTSD symptoms and depression symptoms were significant. However, the direct effect of self-compassion was significant only for depression symptoms, such that higher self-compassion was associated with lower depression symptoms, after shame was included. Self-compassion was not related to PTSD symptoms after rape-related shame was included in the model. Lastly, the indirect effects of self-compassion on PTSD symptoms (b = –5.43, SE = 1.06, 95% CI [–7.64, –3.46]) and depression symptoms (b = –1.37, SE = 0.38, 95% CI [–2.26, –0.72]) were significant as the confidence interval around the indirect effect did not contain zero. This suggests that higher self-compassion is associated with lower rape-related shame, which in turn, is related to lower levels of PTSD and depression symptoms.

Discussion

We investigated whether self-compassion was associated with shame, PTSD and depressive symptoms among women who experienced rape. We found that higher levels of self-compassion were associated with lower levels of rape-related shame, which in turn was associated with lower PTSD and depression symptoms, consistent with our hypotheses and the previous literature (Ross et al., 2019). Further, rape-related shame completely explained the relation between self-compassion and PTSD. This pattern of results in consistent with findings from previous studies where emotion regulation (Scoglio et al., 2018) and experiential avoidance (Seligowski et al., 2015) explained the relation between self-compassion and PTSD. However, these two former studies did not assess for rape, a stigmatized experience, and hence, overlooked the role shame plays in predicting PTSD post-rape. However, these results, in combination with our findings, illustrate the far-reaching benefits of improving self-compassion. Practicing self-compassion not only reduces shame but also fosters improved emotion regulation and decreased experiential avoidance, both of which are also known as powerful predictors of psychopathology (for review see Chawla & Ostafin, 2007; Messman-Moore & Bhuptani, 2017).

The association between self-compassion, shame, PTSD, and depression highlights the importance of reducing self-compassion and shame among rape survivors to reduce PTSD and depression. A growing body of literature has examined self-compassion as a treatment for PTSD and depression among trauma survivors. For example, the Warrior Renew treatment (Katz, 2014) aims at improving self-compassion among survivors of military sexual trauma via perspective taking, cognitive reframing, and imaginal reprocessing (Katz, 2016). Imaginal reprocessing involves having clients imagine interacting with and extending compassion toward their younger self (e.g., hugging the younger self and saying words such as “You’re safe now,” “It was not your fault,” “I love you,” “I will protect you,” “You are important and your needs matter,” etc.). This treatment has been associated with decreased PTSD and depression symptoms among survivors of sexual assault (Katz, 2016; Katz et al., 2008), and compared favorably to empirically supported treatments such as Prolonged Exposure (Katz et al., 2014) and Cognitive Processing (Basharpoor et al., 2013).

Along this vein, another treatment study for PTSD demonstrated benefits of cultivating self-compassion (Hoffart et al., 2015). Participants were provided with either standard prolonged exposure, which includes imaginal exposure to the traumatic memory, or modified prolonged exposure that included imagery rescripting of the memory replaced exposure, with participants instructed to cultivate compassion toward their traumatized self (e.g., by holding or hugging themselves). Imaginal rescripting led to a decrease in self-judgment, isolation, and overidentification, as well as increases in self-kindness. In turn, these aspects of self-compassion were positively associated with the process of therapeutic change. Similarly, loving-kindness meditation was associated with reduced symptoms of PTSD and depression via enhanced self-compassion among veterans in a pilot study (Kearney et al., 2013). Taken together, studies of these three treatments (Hoffart et al., 2015; Katz, 2016; Kearney et al., 2013) suggest self-compassion is a factor in recovery from PTSD and depression. However, none of these studies examined intermediary factors that may explain how self-compassion reduces PTSD and depression symptoms. Our results add to this body of literature and suggest that shame may explain the relation between increased self-compassion and reduced distress symptoms.

Shame among sexual assault survivors does not develop in a vacuum. Rather, it emerges from victim-blaming messages that are entrenched in media representations, dominant narratives, stereotypes, or unsupportive responses to assault disclosure (Ahrens, 2006; Ahrens et al., 2010). Survivors of sexual assault may internalize these messages and engage in self-blame. Self-blame has been known to exacerbate shame among survivors and led to PTSD and depression (Alix et al., 2017; Zinzow & Thompson, 2011). Given the close relationship between blame and shame, one can expect that improvements in self-compassion would reduce self-blame as well. Indeed, higher self-compassion is associated with lower levels of self-blame, which in turn is associated with lower levels of PTSD and depression among female survivors of sexual assault (Hamrick & Owens, 2019). While it was beyond the scope of this study, future studies should empirically investigate whether self-compassion would have an equal impact both self-blame and shame when considered together

Limitations and Future Directions

The current study supports the important role of self-compassion in relation to assault-related shame, PTSD, and depression symptoms. Yet, these findings must be tempered by study limitations. Most notably, the retrospective, cross-sectional design limits conclusions regarding the directionality of effects as well as the causal nature of relations found. It may be possible that decreased PTSD or depression symptoms lead to improved self-compassion via decreased shame, instead of the other way around. There is longitudinal evidence that self-compassion predicts PTSD and depression (Zeller et al., 2015), whereas there is no such evidence that PTSD or depression predict self-compassion. Thus, we have increased confidence in our results. However, future studies could investigate the temporal and causal relations among PTSD or depression, shame, and self-compassion over time. It is likely that variables are associated via reciprocal processes where increases in self-compassion would lead to decreases in depression PTSD symptoms, which then would lead to further improvements in self-compassion. In addition, the current design and assessment limits our ability to capture the enduring and dynamic nature of shame and its potential cyclical impact on distress. To truly understand the relation among these variables, longitudinal studies with more than two time points are needed. Such studies may increase confidence in the findings of the studies and may also assist in teasing apart the nature of relation among these constructs.

Generalization of the current findings are limited given the homogenous nature of our sample. Notably, the study sample was predominantly white, cisgender college females which precludes examination of how age, race, gender, ethnicity, educational status, and other relevant demographics may impact the variables of interests as well as relations between them. Given how research on trauma has overlooked the impact of intersecting identities on recovery (Bryant-Davis, 2019), it is vital to determine how they affect self-compassion and shame. Preliminary research suggests that levels of self-compassion are higher amongst female African American college students when compared to female European American (Miron et al., 2014). Meanwhile, another study among multiracial South Africans noted that individuals identifying with white Afrikaans culture reported experiencing less shame compared to black, colored, or Indian Afrikaan cultures (Mayer & Viviers, 2017). Further, a qualitative study found that sexual minority adolescents of color view their sexual identity through the lens of their racial identity, which may exacerbate shame (Flores & Davalos, 2019). While the literature on how diverse identities influence shame and self-compassion is still nascent, different factors (e.g., minority stressors, religiosity) may impact how self-compassion and shame operate differently across different populations (Messman-Moore & Bhuptani, 2017). In conclusion, our results suggest that self-compassion has an indirect effect on PTSD and depression via assault-related shame, among women who have experienced rape. More studies are needed to establish causality among these variables and examine how other demographic factors impact these relations.

Implications

A large body of research indicates that shame is a powerful predictor of a more persistent, or long-lasting course of PTSD and depression (Andrews et al., 2002; Feiring & Taska, 2005). Since improvements in shame drive improvements in PTSD and depression (Goldsmith et al., 2014a; Judge et al., 2012), it is important that clinicians develop methods to address shame when it arises in the therapy room. Extant interventions for assault-related PTSD, including cognitive processing therapy (CPT; Resick et al., 2008) and skills training in affective and interpersonal regulation with prolonged exposure (STAIR; Cloitre et al., 2011) focus on reducing shame by addressing maladaptive cognitions and dysfunctional schemas. Our results suggest that improving self-compassion may be another approach to reduce shame among rape survivors by promoting self-kindness and mindfulness and decreasing isolation. Self-compassion promotes kindness and understanding toward oneself and encourages a more holistic view of where the blame for negative events truly lie. Further, self-compassion fosters a nonjudgmental awareness of negative emotions. These skills can directly counteract the painful and emotionally overwhelming effects of shame, which in turn leads to reduction in depression and PTSD symptoms. Indeed, compassion-based interventions have demonstrated effectiveness in reducing shame, and subsequent decreases in PTSD symptom severity (e.g., Au et al., 2017; Johnson & O’Brien, 2013).

JULIAN TOMPKIN

On August 10, 1942, a young man in the Victorian town of Tatura began a letter in hurried script. "My dear Mother! In case you get this letter, you probably know why. I took my chance and failed." Along with a brief will and testament declaring his mother his sole beneficiary, the letter would be Ulrich Alexander Boschwitz's final recorded word.

Seven days later the 27-year-old exiled German author boarded the MV Abosso bound for Britain. Two months into the journey, on October 30 - so grippingly close to safe harbour - the boat would be torpedoed by a Nazi U-boat in the Atlantic. Boschwitz, with his revised 1939 novel Der Reisende (The Traveller) reportedly strapped to his body, would perish along with 361 others, his body never recovered.

Interred as a prisoner of war in Australia, Boschwitz had been delaying his return to Europe after being reclassified a refugee, wary of being drafted by the Allies into a war against his own countrymen. A German of both Jewish and Protestant ancestry, he had fled Berlin with his mother Martha in 1935 trailing the Jewish intelligentsia to Scandinavia, as Nazi pugnacity towards Germany's Jewish population rapidly decayed from enmity to unmitigated brutality.

Despite his young age and the existential tumult of abandoning his family's life and significant fortune in Berlin, Boschwitz completed and published his first novel, Menschen neben dem Leben (People Parallel To Life), in 1937 under the anglicised pen name John Grane, before continuing his restive migration through Paris, Luxembourg and Belgium. Here, he would complete his second novel in just a matter of weeks: an urgent response to the November 1938 pogroms in the Reich. First released in Sweden, The Traveller would be published in the UK and US respectively as The Fugitive and The Man Who Took Trains.

Set in Germany in the immediate aftermath of Kristallnacht, the novel - which traces the travails of a wealthy Jewish businessman trying to dodge capture - received mixed reviews on publication, with The Times Literary Supplement dismissing the novel as unrealistic as well as "inconclusive, allusive ... characteristic of immature writing". The Glasgow Herald would prove more receptive, writing: "With dreadful clarity Mr Grane presents the spectacle of a civilised man travelling round and round Germany like a beast encircled by a forest fire ..." In a world now all-consumed with war, the book would vanish into the cinders of Europe's burning cities.

Boschwitz himself recognised the novel's faults - its cumbrous dialogue and frustrating narrative progress - but also understood its edifying potential. With war now declared in Europe he absconded to the UK seeking asylum, only to be arrested and interred as an enemy alien in June 1940. Two months later he would be marched onto an overcrowded ship alongside Italian fascists and Nazi POWs, believing he was destined for Canada. Sailing through nauseating Atlantic swell, the ship made a sudden pivot south, traversed its way around the Horn of Africa and trained its bow towards the distant continent of Australia.

The Jewish prisoners aboard - composed of many notable philosophers, scientists and artists - would become endearingly known as the Dunera Boys. Winston Churchill would later call their grievous treatment on the Dunera and remote exile as POWs "a deplorable mistake". Boschwitz would reportedly be robbed by British soldiers on the arduous journey and have a manuscript tossed overboard.

While in Australia, first interred at Hay in NSW and later in Tatura, Boschwitz drafted two new novels and wholly revised The Traveller in the hope of finally having it released in Germany. By mid-1942 most of the 2542 Dunera Boys - including Sigmund Freud's grandson Walter - had either returned to Europe to join the Allied war effort or been released into the community in Australia, where many went on to become prominent members of Australian society, including decorated athletics coach Franz Stampfl and physicist Hans Adolf Buchdahl.

Prior to his own departure Boschwitz wrote his final letter to his mother, extolling The Traveller: "I really believe there is something in this book, which may make it a success". In the event of his death he implored her to continue the campaign to have the novel released in what he hoped to be a newly liberated Germany, adding that he had sent a partial redraft ahead with a fellow intern. He boarded the MV Abosso with his own copy. Neither manuscript has ever been recovered.

In 2015 Berlin-based publisher Peter Graf received an email from Israel. As a publisher with a reputation for rehabilitating long-forgotten works of German literature - including Blood Brothers by Ernst Haffner, which traverses the gritty underworld of Berlin in the 1930s - the correspondent, Reuella Shachaf, enquired as to whether Graf was aware of the novel, The Traveller, authored by her late uncle Ulrich Boschwitz. The original unedited 1938 manuscript, she informed him, was kept in the German Exile Archive in Frankfurt. Intrigued, Graf travelled west to Germany's financial capital.

"I was curious about this text, but had no particular expectations," Graf explains to Review from his home in Berlin. The pages were jaundiced with time, but the text still legible. "When I read it, I was quickly aware that it was a significant but unrevised novel. It is a cruel book and for that very reason a manifesto of humanity, a reminder and a gift to us. And the way it is written, stylistically and dramaturgically, is very remarkable, especially when you know that the author was 23 years old when the work was written."

Graf began trawling what little archival material there was on Boschwitz, mostly a small cache of papers housed at the Centre For Jewish History in New York, including the final letter to his mother. Here he learned of Boschwitz's last wishes, to have the work edited and released in German, and resolved to complete the task with the blessing from the extended family in Israel. Released in 2019 into a radically different Germany to that in which it was cast, the edited novel would be proclaimed by German critics as "one of the most important books of the year" and "an incredibly gripping rediscovery". Multiple translations ensued (20 to date), with the revised edition now available in English, resurrected as The Passenger, translated by Philip Boehm and published locally by Allen & Unwin.

The novel traces the frenetic footsteps of Otto Silbermann, a Bourgeois Jewish scrap metal dealer in Berlin. Amidst the clang of Kristallnacht he calmly goes about his business, certain in his social stature until there comes a fateful knock at the door: "Open up, Jew, open up ..." So begins a desperate, anxious and often tragicomic attempt to elude what we now know to be such a dystopian endgame.

The earliest known novel penned in direct response to Kristallnacht and the subsequent pogroms, The Passenger is less a comment on the rise of the Nazis than a documentary of the degradation of human dignity. As Nazi oppression begins to choke, Silbermann's longtime friends, fellow Great War veterans and business partners, sense their opportunity to fleece him of every last pfennig. He watches helplessly as German turns on German, Jew on Jew, in a hideous orgy of avarice and desperation.

Feeling somewhat invulnerable with a briefcase stuffed with Deutsche marks and a discernibly Aryan complexion, Silbermann haplessly sets off for Hamburg by train: commencing an equally farcical and desperate flight that hightails through Germany, as he tries to evade the spectre of both opprobrium and oppression. The novel would channel the author's own flight from Berlin as well as the conundrum of his own mixed ancestry. As Boschwitz's Australian Military Forces prisoner of war file would coolly record: Protestant, dark blonde hair, blue eyes.

Written two years before the Wannsee Conference, The Passenger captures the nascent absurdity of the political dehumanisation of the Jewish population. Attempting to mollify Silbermann about his newly acquired pariah status, one Aryan colleague consoles: "A lot of bad things happen in the world. And some good things as well. Today it's this person, tomorrow that one ... That's the way it is."

Silbermann fossicks for empathy with his tormentors, even feeling compunctious for thrashing one particularly witless Nazi in six consecutive games of chess.

"Did you notice," a fellow passenger comments, ignorant to Silbermann's Jewishness, "that the whole first class is full of Jews. Half of Israel is on tour."

He bides his time drinking beer and taking long lunches of roasted goose leg in train-station restaurants, perversely reading trashy paperback murder mysteries to take his mind off his own existential calamity. Purchasing a ticket to Munich he muses: "At least I'll get to know Germany."

In the shadow of history's inexpungible scar of the Holocaust, Silbermann's indifference to his situation can prove frustrating. But we only need to look to the recent storming of the US Capitol to understand how rapidly the wholly inconceivable can become tenable.

"This novel, which is over 80 years old, now comes to the surface like a message in a bottle and is read at a time when flight and expulsion are taking place worldwide, with the same mechanisms as then," Graf suggests. "Human dramas take place every day under the eyes of the world public, but most of them remain nameless."

Despite the increasingly desperate situation, the married Silbermann (his wife a Protestant, and safe from harm) schemes an illicit rendezvous with a much younger Aryan woman he meets on a train, who sardonically notes the inconvenience of having German aesthetics but "not a very fortunate" surname. "I'm completely at the mercy of chance," Silbermann resolves. "It's almost as though the subject has become the object."

As he moves across Germany, he desperately tries to avoid fraternising with Jewish colleagues who might betray his "ethnic curse". In one darkly comic yet deeply disturbing scene, sensing a fellow sufferer's fatalistic acceptance of his destiny due to the size of his nose, Silbermann attempts to cheer him up by complimenting the gentleman on his business acumen: "You'll even manage to make money off the rope they hang you with".

The man responds mirthfully: "I should hope so ... Otherwise how would my wife be able to pay for her widow's veil?"

The situation quickly degenerates and the trenchant wisecracks peel away as Silbermann faces up to the wretchedness of his people's persecution. The colour bleeds from the endless rolling landscape into monochrome beyond the glass of the train window, as does his command over his own identity. "They'll slowly undress us first and then kill us, so our clothes won't get bloody and our banknotes won't get damaged."

"A good minority is still better than a bad majority," Boschwitz would write all too optimistically from his long exile. His premature death would extricate him from ever knowing how this nascent campaign of oppression against his people would turn so macabre. Eight decades on, The Passenger remains terrifyingly prescient.

urn:contentItem:62R7-H511-JBJ7-N51R-00000-00Risk v reward: Why Morrison may go to the polls early2021-05-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:42ZLexisNexisRisk v reward: Why Morrison may go to the polls earlyDavid Crowe

Fear of the coronavirus seems stronger than ever despite the country's extraordinary success against COVID-19. That fear has the power to decide the next election.

National anxiety over the next phase of the pandemic has reached a point where some Australians believe an early election is the best way to settle the politics, give federal leaders a mandate and steer the nation out of crisis.

"We would love to see an early election," says one business leader who is frustrated at the way populism rules the debate over the policies needed this year and beyond.

Fear of the coronavirus seems stronger than ever despite the country's extraordinary success against COVID-19. That fear has the power to decide the next election. So much power, in fact, that no political leader will take the risk of swimming against the tide.

Those who have to deal with political leaders have to be careful about what they say, but they know they will be forced to wait until after the election before they find out when the federal government will open the international border. The sooner the election, the sooner everyone knows the answer.

Scott Morrison sees this national mood and knows how to put it to use. He has adjusted his message to Australians in the past two weeks to warn of greater dangers ahead, to the point where he seems to stoke the fears.

Four months ago, when the country emerged from summer lockdowns and border closures, the Prime Minister thought the risks were subsiding. Confident that vaccines were on their way, he said COVID-19 could present a similar risk to many other viruses already in the community.

"What I'm saying is that the risk environment is reducing," he said on February 5.

Not any more. Morrison now argues the pandemic is a greater threat than it was one year ago. "The pandemic is raging. The pandemic is morphing. It's changing every day," he said last Tuesday. "I'm not going to take risks with Australians' lives."

When Virgin chief executive Jayne Hrdlicka called for a road map to open the borders but made her unwise remark that "some people may die" from the pandemic, Morrison made no attempt to acknowledge her case for a clear plan to open the country. He slapped down the remark as "insensitive" and said it was difficult to "have any truck" with what she was saying.

So Morrison does not want to calm the farm. He wants to talk about the forest fire next door.

A clear majority wants this caution. The Resolve Political Monitor, published by The Sydney Morning Herald and The Age on Tuesday, shows overwhelming support for border controls at a time when 3.4 million people have died from COVID-19 worldwide.

Asked about the federal budget assumption the border will stay closed until the middle of next year, 44 per cent said this was about right and 33 per cent said it was too optimistic. Only 9 per cent thought it was too pessimistic. Those who want a faster plan to open the border are clearly in the minority.

The same survey, based on responses from 1622 voters online in the five days after the budget, also showed majority support for the overall budget strategy, with 62 per cent agreeing with the priority of stimulus spending. Only 17 per cent prefer action on deficits and debt.

Yet there is a caution on another front, too. The survey found 29 per cent of respondents were reluctant to take a vaccine against the coronavirus in the months ahead. To be exact, 14 per cent said they were "not very likely" and 15 per cent said they were "not at all likely" to do so.

The survey found 35 per cent had registered for a vaccine or had already received one or two doses. It also found a separate 14 per cent were extremely likely to be vaccinated, 8 per cent were very likely to do so and 13 per cent were fairly likely to do so.

The government has its own surveys showing similar concerns, which helps explain why Morrison said he was "not overly troubled" by the results.

This is true of other results in Resolve Political Monitor, too. The survey reveals what the government knows. The Liberal Party's polling is finding the same reluctance to open the border. Morrison reflects the mood of the focus groups with his new tone.

Morrison has been testing his new message since the May 11 budget, when Treasurer Josh Frydenberg outlined $74.6 billion in new spending on aged care, tax cuts, mental health, skills, disability services and more. Day by day, he has honed the message to be ready for the election.

And the Coalition goes to the election with a majority of one in the lower house, a starting position with no political capital to spare. Morrison has to craft his message to capture the national mood.

On vaccines, he wants older Australians to take the AstraZeneca jab but is not going to force the issue in a way that provokes a backlash. It's a free country, he says. And he is right. The government is in no position to dictate this personal decision when more supplies from Pfizer and Moderna are due to arrive. But this is one area where Morrison's warnings about the pandemic could deliver a policy gain by convincing people to roll up their sleeves.

On borders, he is deliberately vague. The government suggests it will open the international borders in the middle of 2022. This is central to the federal budget, which is a policy document authored by ministers. But Morrison presents the date as merely an assumption.

On quarantine he is passive. He waits for state leaders to come to him with proposals and chooses some, such as the plan for a new facility in or near Melbourne, and rejects others, such as the sketchy proposal for Toowoomba. The last big federal initiative, to expand Howard Springs in the Northern Territory, was finalised in December. Morrison seeks to avoid the risk of making quarantine a greater federal responsibility.

Even so, the government neglects the Australian employers and communities that need a road map to open borders. Margy Osmond, the chief executive of the Tourism and Transport Forum, says anyone who depends on tourism is in "diabolical" trouble and the daily political doorstops, with ideas like vaccine passports, are not helping.

"There are too many different communications circulating all over the shop," she says. "There is a desperate need for some sort of national unity."

Yet national cabinet is back to meeting once every month. There is no sense of the urgency that led Morrison to put the peak group on an "operational footing" just six weeks ago.

While Morrison seems too cautious for some business leaders, he is in tune with scientists on the continuing risks.

"The PM is correct the pandemic is changing," says Mary-Louise McLaws, an epidemiologist at the University of NSW. "Pandemics shouldn't be viewed from a linear perspective as there are many facilitators that do not have equal impact and some that have more impact than the sum of each."

Those factors include the vaccination rate and the variants overseas. Getting things wrong, says McLaws, could quickly throw Australia into another wave of infection.

Just as Australians want to play it safe, so does Morrison.

For the moment, the political imperative is to keep people anxious until their votes are counted. The path to policy certainty runs through the ballot box. No wonder some want to get there as fast as possible.

urn:contentItem:60G4-9431-JB75-93TJ-00000-00Under climate change, winter will be the best time for bush burn-offs - and that could be bad news for public health2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:42ZLexisNexisUnder climate change, winter will be the best time for bush burn-offs - and that could be bad news for public healthGiovanni Di Virgilio, Research associate, UNSW

New research has found the window of opportunity for hazard reduction burns won't actually get smaller, but instead change seasons.

At the height of last summer's fires, some commentators claimed "greenies" were preventing hazard reduction burns - also known as prescribed burns - in cooler months. They argued that such burns would have reduced the bushfire intensity.

Fire experts repeatedly dismissed these claims. As then NSW Rural Fire Service Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons noted in January this year, the number of available days to carry out prescribed burns had reduced because climate change was altering the weather and causing longer fire seasons.

Read more: How does bushfire smoke affect our health? 6 things you need to know

This public conversation led our research team to ask: if climate change continues at its current rate, how will this change the days suitable for prescribed burning?

Our results, published today, were unexpected. Climate change may actually increase the number of burn days in some places, but the windows of opportunity will shift towards winter months. The bad news is that burning during these months potentially increases the public health impacts of smoke.

A hot debate

Hazard reduction involves removing vegetation that could otherwise fuel a fire, including burning under controlled conditions. But its effectiveness to subdue or prevent fires is often debated in the scientific community.

Those with experience on fire grounds, including Fitzsimmons, say it's an important factor in fire management, but "not a pancea".

Despite the debate, it's clear hazard reduction burning will continue to be an important part of bushfire risk management in coming decades.

Read more: The burn legacy: why the science on hazard reduction is contested

Modelling future weather

Before conducting prescribed burns, firefighting agencies consider factors such as vegetation type, proximity to property, desired rate of spread and possible smoke dispersal over populated areas. But we wanted to distil our investigation down to daily weather factors.

We reduced those factors to five key components. These were maximum temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, fuel moisture and the McArthur forest fire danger index (the index used to forecast fire danger in southeast Australia).

We looked at these elements on prescribed burning days between 2004-2015. We then used climate models to simulate how the conditions would change with global warming over southeast Australia, relative to a baseline historical 20-year period for 1990-2009.

To make a valid 20-year comparison, we compared the historical period to a modelled period from 2060-2079, assuming emissions continue to rise at their current pace.

Surprisingly, we found, with one regional exception, the number of days suitable for prescribed burning did not change. And in many places, the number increased.

As the fire season lengthened under a warming climate, the number of days suitable for burning just shifted from autumn to winter.

Shifting seasons

Our research indicated that by 2060 there'll be fewer prescribed burning days during March, April and May. These are the months when most burning happens now.

But there will be significantly more opportunities for burning days from June to October. This is because the conditions that make for a good day for prescribed burning - such as mild and still days - start to shift to winter. Today, weather in these months is unsuitable for conducting burns.

Interestingly, these results aren't uniform across southeast Australia. For example, much of the Australian east coast and South Australia would see seasonal shifts in burning windows, with around 50% fewer burning days in March to May.

Much of Victoria and in particular the southern regions saw an increase in burning windows during April to May and, in some parts of the state, through September and October as well.

Only the east Queensland coast would see a total reduction in prescribed burn days from April to October.

The smoke trap

This may be good news for firefighters and those agencies who depend on prescribed burning as a key tool in bushfire prevention. But, as so often is the case with climate change, it's not that simple.

A byproduct of prescribed burning is smoke, and it's a very significant health issue.

Last year, research showed global warming will strengthen an atmospheric layer that traps pollution close to the land surface, known as the "inversion layer". This will happen in the years 2060-79, relative to 1990-2009 - especially during winter.

Read more: The smoke from autumn burn-offs could make coronavirus symptoms worse. It's not worth the risk

Unfortunately, the conditions that create inversion layers - including cool, still air - correspond with conditions suitable for prescribed burning.

For asthmatics and those sensitive to air pollution, smokier burn days could make winter months more difficult and add further stress to the health system.

It also creates an additional challenge for firefighting agencies, which must already consider whether smoke will linger close to the surface and potentially drift into populated regions during prescribed burns.

This is just one factor our firefighting agencies will need to face in the future as bushfire risk management becomes more complex and challenging under climate change.

urn:contentItem:60DH-TJ01-JBN5-F358-00000-00Donald Trump's first coronavirus briefing in months involved a stark warning for America2020-07-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:42ZLexisNexisDonald Trump's first coronavirus briefing in months involved a stark warning for AmericaBy Emily Olson

Donald Trump sticks to the script as he launches himself back into the spotlight with daily coronavirus briefings again. But we've seen this play out before, Emily Olson writes.

In his first formal coronavirus briefing since April, US President Donald Trump stuck to a prepared script, urged Americans to wear masks and warned that things would "get worse before they get better".

In other words, he treated COVID-19, which has killed more than 140,000 Americans, like a threat.

It's a long cry from his comments just two days ago, when he compared climbing case numbers to "little embers" rather than, say, a forest fire.

"We have embers and fires and big fires," he backpedalled in today's briefing.

"As one family, we mourn every precious life that's been lost. I pledge in their honour that we will develop a vaccine, and we will defeat the virus.

"My administration will stop at nothing to save lives and shield the vulnerable."

But there's still ammo for Trump's critics

This is hardly the first time the President has backflipped on his stance since the start of the US outbreak.

He likened COVID-19 to a flu throughout much of January and February.

Then he agreed with the scientists that a lockdown was necessary in March.

In early April, he said governors should be responsible for the US response, and by the month's end, he was calling for an abrupt end to nationwide lockdowns and threatening to use his power to make it so.

His latest comments end a three-month period of insisting life is back to normal, but they still leave plenty of ammo for his critics.

Unlike the previous briefings, the 27 minutes of guidance came from Trump and Trump alone, as the medical experts on the White House's Coronavirus Task Force stayed outside the briefing room.

That left no-one but the President to dole out the statistics, facts and scientific reasoning behind his points.

Some of his claims that appeared tailor-made to paint the US as superior to other countries will no doubt be picked apart for being misleading.

He pointed to a chart claiming the US had the world's lowest mortality rate, while Johns Hopkins University figures rank the US seventh highest.

"If you watch television you'd think that the US is the only country suffering from the China virus," Trump said in one of his comments that directly or indirectly blamed China for the pandemic.

Phrases like "the virus will disappear one day" and "we'll end up with a cure soon" also surfaced in the briefing.

Perhaps the briefing was meant to reassure the portion of the public that's panicked. But health experts have warned such comments also run the risk of lulling those who are weary of coronavirus restrictions into a false sense of security.

The mask tweet told us this was coming

The decision to resume daily briefings was announced not long after the President tweetedthat wearing a mask was "patriotic," a first hint of his sudden reversal.

The White House press secretary said Trump had "been consistent on the issue of masks" and cited the President's frequent testing regime as proof he is "acting appropriately" and setting an example.

The President did not wear a mask at today's briefing, which is consistent with all but three of his public appearances since the start of the outbreak, but he did pull one out of his pocket to illustrate a point about his willingness.

"I will use the mask gladly," he said, adding he often puts it on when he's near others, like in elevators.

"I have no problem with the masks. I view it this way. Anything that can help is a good thing."

Though he said a return to lockdowns would be "unfeasible" at this stage, Trump encouraged social distancing, hand-washing and general vigilance.

He pleaded with young Americans, who appear to be driving the outbreaks in the southern states, to stop attending bars and gatherings.

He promised his administration was working to speed up tests, which are taking 10 or more days to return results in some regions.

He pledged he'd help governors with whatever supplies they needed.

But in most cases, he stopped short of elaborating on the specifics, opting for message over mechanics.

He ended his briefing by reminding reporters he'd be back tomorrow.

We're still a long way from the election

Even while Trump managed to stay somewhat on-message when it came to coronavirus, he still bestowed his good wishes on Ghislaine Maxwell, the former partner of disgraced paedophile financier Jeffrey Epstein.

"I don't know, I haven't really been following it too much. I just wish her well, frankly," Trump responded when asked about the charges she faces of transporting minors for illegal sexual acts.

"I have met her numerous times over the years, especially since I lived in Palm Beach, and I guess they lived in Palm Beach. But I wish her well, whatever it is."

The White House briefing room has always been a dangerous place for a President who tends to stray from the script.

Plenty have speculated that Trump's motivation for resuming the briefings involves rescuing his sagging poll numbers.

Trump continues to trail Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden by an average of nine points as US COVID-19 case numbers rise above 3.8 million and the unemployment rate hovers around 11 per cent.

And with the Trump campaign still reeling from an embarrassing turnout in Tulsa, Oklahoma, it's clear the virus has prohibitively diminished the ability to hold rallies, Trump's signature campaign tool.

We don't know if and how daily briefings will influence the President's re-election chances, but we do know the President has launched himself back into the spotlight today.

We'll see what tomorrow brings.

urn:contentItem:5XYN-KTF1-JD3N-50VK-00000-00Herald Sun2020-01-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:42ZLexisNexisOPEDPg. 24Herald Sun

Let's not forget fireys TRAGIC news of another life lost in Victorian bushfires has come as a stark reminder that the crisis gripping our state is far from over.

Bill Slade, 60, was a long-serving firefighter who spent decades caring for national parks while working with Forest Fire Management Victoria.

He will always be remembered for the heroic sacrifice he made while working to minimise the risk to homes and property near Omeo.

His death, along with the loss of Mat Kavanagh, Mick Roberts and Fred Becker, highlights the lethal nature of these horrific blazes and the many different ways in which they can shatter families forever.

But as conditions on the fireground improve and many Victorians return to work today, the temptation will be to assume everyday life is returning to normal.

Sadly this could not be further from the truth for our heroes. The fire season has only just begun and there is every indication that this summer there will be more potentially deadly episodes.

Drought-ravaged parts of the state are still at risk and long-term weather forecasts expect more tinder dry conditions.

Similarly, the fires are not extinguished in East Gippsland and the state's northeast.

Dozens of blazes are still burning and a "mega fire" straddling the border with New South Wales will continue to create headaches for emergency services.

FFMV chief officer Chris Hardman said yesterday the fight was far from over. "We need to be really clear that unless we get really significant rains â€¦ We're going to be in this for the long haul," he said.

"We will be working on these fires right through until the end of February, into March and possibly beyond.

"We will be putting our firefighters out there to do everything they can to contain these fires and stop them running into communities." Premier Daniel Andrews and Emergency Management Victoria Commissioner Andrew Crisp have also been vocal that the danger is still very real.

Bushfire Recovery Victoria, a new agency to lead rebuilding efforts, has been established as a permanent fixture to cope with what is expected to be the new status quo.

It is grim news for many communities and for the hundreds of volunteers and professionals who have spent their holidays in disastrous conditions with little time to see the families and loved ones they are battling to protect.

Australians have shown great generosity over this difficult period. We have come together to help those in need and put petty differences aside when necessary to ensure lives are protected and people receive vital support.

While we try to shake off the fog and come out of "holiday mode" one of the most important things we can do is remember those we have lost and those still fighting to save lives.

The natural impulse will be to focus on what happens next.

Frank and fearless discussion must be had about the impact of our changing climate on fire danger and what steps authorities can take to mitigate future risk to lives and property.

Current funding models, hazard reduction plans and government strategies should all be examined.

As this happens we should also continue to keep in mind the brave work being done by those on the frontline of this mammoth crisis.

Run for their lives THERE is nothing more precious than a baby born - and Paul Abbey knows this more than most.

Mr Abbey's daughter, Lottie, was born very prematurely, at 27 weeks, so it was touch and go whether she would make it.

But as today's Herald Sun reports, Lottie, who weighed only 761 grams at birth, pulled through, and now she's a bright and determined two-year-old.

Mr Abbey and wife Hayley, who also have a daughter Sadie, cannot be more thankful to staff at the Royal Children's Hospital for saving Lottie.

Mr Abbey is a keen participant in the Herald Sun/Transurban Run for the Kids, an annual event that has raised more than $17 million for the hospital's Good Friday Appeal.

Last year's event was especially poignant for the Maidstone dad, as Lottie was being treated in hospital at the time.

Mr Abbey, who raised more than $11,000 last year, said he was determined to give something back to a world-class facility that did so much good for Victoria.

He will also take part in this year's event - to be held on Sunday, March 29 - and hopes to raise a similar amount of money.

Tens of thousands of runners pounded the pavement in 2019, helping to raise $1.5 million for the appeal.

Debuting in 2006, Run for the Kids has grown to become one of the state's biggest mass participation fun runs.

Registrations for the 2020 event open today, with details at runforthekids.com.auPaul Abbey will be there, running for Lottie, and other kids.

urn:contentItem:5XY2-8N41-JD34-V3HP-00000-00Rainbow patron safety could not be guaranteed says Pyrenees Shire2020-01-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:42ZLexisNexisRainbow patron safety could not be guaranteed says Pyrenees Shire

Update

PYRENEES Shire Mayor Tanya Kehoe says organisers could simply not guarantee patron safety after recent bushfires near Lexton, which have forced the postponement of the Rainbow Serpent Festival.

Cr Kehoe says a multi-agency review of the efficacy of Rainbow Serpent Festival 2020 this week found that the event could not be safely held at Lexton on Australia Day long weekend.

"The safety of patrons and staff has always been the number one priority for the Rainbow Serpent Festival," Pyrenees Shire Council Mayor Tanya Kehoe said.

"We share the Rainbow Serpent Festival's disappointment that the event could not be held, but are looking forward to working with them on the new-look Rainbow Serpent Festival 2020 and welcoming festival goers back to Lexton later in the year."

Festival organisers have announced plans to hold the 2020 Festival in two stages, with a one-day event in Melbourne on January 26, and a second event at Lexton over Easter.

Festival organisers have also announced plans to assist with the recovery following the fire, with community- related events including tree planting, a working bee, and the delayed opening of the Servo@23 Arts Hub in Beaufort.

"This was a difficult call to make, but it was the correct call based on the current state of emergency in Victoria," Cr Kehoe said.

"We thank Festival organisers for putting patron safety first, and Festival patrons for their patience while this decision was made."

The Lexton-Ben Major Fire burned approximately 3000 hectares on December 20 and 21 2019.

Pyrenees Shire Council will present its Recovery Implementation Plan at the Council Meeting on Tuesday January 21

Earlier

ORGANISERS of the Rainbow Serpent Festival say they have had no option but to reschedule this year's event due to recent fires at Lexton which damaged part of the venue.

In a statement put on its website on Wednesday night, organisers say they will instead run a one-day event on Australia Day in Melbourne before inviting revellers to return over the Easter weekend for a special 'Regen' edition which aims to showcase what the festival has to offer.

The statement reads:

"Firstly, we'd like to thank the Rainbow community for your incredible patience during these stressful times. No one could have predicted the intensity of the fires we've witnessed around the country over the last two weeks and it's been a sobering experience for us all.

"During this time, our key stakeholders have been busy using their expertise where they are needed the most. Particularly, the CFA.

"It hasn't been an easy decision to know what is the right path forward - as much as we all love RSF, the health and safety of patrons and crew is our number one priority.

"This is key to any decisions made and of course, we always consider our impact and commitment to the land and the local community.

"This morning we undertook a meeting and inspection onsite with the CFA, Victoria Police, Forest Fire Management Victoria and Pyrenees Council staff. Due to a number of safety concerns stemming from the fire that affected the site and the wider bushfire impacts across the country, it was agreed that holding RSF over the scheduled weekend in Lexton simply isn't the right thing to do."

The statement said the two new events would honour the spirit of the festival.

"The two events will be treated as Rainbow Serpent Festival 2020 with your tickets gaining entry to both.

"(In Melbourne) Multiple stages hosting the majority of special guest performers from the original lineup. There is still quite a lot of work to do to rearrange schedules and travel arrangements so please bear with us for a couple of days before confirming these details.

"(At Lexton) A special multi-day event on site during the Easter long weekend, showcasing the best that Rainbow has to offer.

"This event is important for the rebuilding of the local communities that were directly impacted by the fires and boosting their local economy. As well as your Rainbow favourites, we'll be hosting a number of community related events including tree planting, a community working bee and the delayed opening of the Servo@23 Arts Hub.

"We're looking into how we can best use these events to drive a community fundraising effort for the bushfires and will confirm those details in the coming days."

For people unable to attend either or both events, the organisers say they will announce details for full and partial refunds n coming days.

"We ask everyone to please be sympathetic to the needs and wellbeing of the broader community at this time but also the incredible strain our crew are currently experiencing in trying to work towards an outcome that is acceptable, enjoyable and safe," the statement said.

"By supporting us and attending both these events you are helping to secure the future of Rainbow Serpent Festival and our continued work in partnership with the Pyrenees community."

urn:contentItem:5XXV-JBT1-DY19-C3NS-00000-00Year of extremes as record heat, fire danger and dismal rainfall dominate2020-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:21:42ZLexisNexisYear of extremes as record heat, fire danger and dismal rainfall dominatePeter Hannam

Australia sweltered through its seven hottest days in December, in a searing end to 2019 that melted many records.

Australia sweltered through its seven hottest days in December, melting many records including for the country's highest fire danger and its warmest and driest year.

The Bureau of Meteorology said maximum and mean temperatures for 2019 were easily the warmest in data going back to 1910. Daytime temperatures were 2.09 degrees above the 1961-90 average, beating the previous high set in 2013 by 0.54 degrees. Annual mean temperatures were 1.52 degrees above the norm.

Globally, 2019 was also the second hottest year on record based on data going back to 1880. It will be the warmest for any year that did not have an El Nino event - a Pacific climate pattern that boosts temperatures - and means the past five years are all among the top five warmest.

While short-term climate drivers, particularly in the Indian Ocean, contributed to Australia's hot year, the background warming - caused by rising greenhouse gas emissions - is clear.

"We've seen clear trends in maximum, minimum and average temperatures across Australia," said Karl Braganza, head of the bureau's climate monitoring, adding the country had warmed about 1.4 degrees since 1910, most of it since 1950.

"We've seen quite clear trends in reducing rainfall across south-west WA and parts of the south-east," he said.

Sydney, Canberra, Brisbane and Hobart notched their warmest year on record for daytime temperatures, while Perth was equal-warmest and Darwin the second-warmest. Exposure to cool westerlies kept a lid on the mercury for Melbourne, but it too had above-average maximums.

NSW broke its annual record for daytime temperatures for a third year in a row, while Victoria had its fourth-warmest. For South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory, 2019 also marked their hottest year for maximums.

Drought intensifies

Rainfall was generally dismal, averaging just 277.63 millimetres across Australia in 2019. That tally was more than one-10th below the previous record low set in 1902.

"Australia had below-average rainfall in every month - it's the first time that's happened," Dr Braganza said.

Each city, except Sydney, had rainfall totals in the driest 10 per cent of years. The city had many months with below-average rainfall and ended up with its driest year since 2005.

NSW and the Murray-Darling Basin both collected less than half their usual annual rainfall, setting new lows and intensifying the drought.

South Australia also had its driest year, with one-third its typical falls, while Victoria had its 10th-driest at just below two-thirds of normal levels.

Three poor winters meant run-off into dams in the Murray-Darling Basin was also very poor, with "no meaningful inflows in the northern basin where storages remained extremely low or close to empty", the bureau said in its annual report.

Year-end blowtorch

Update

PYRENEES Shire Mayor Tanya Kehoe says organisers could simply not guarantee patron safety after recent bushfires near Lexton, which have forced the postponement of the Rainbow Serpent Festival.

Cr Kehoe says a multi-agency review of the efficacy of Rainbow Serpent Festival 2020 this week found that the event could not be safely held at Lexton on Australia Day long weekend.

"The safety of patrons and staff has always been the number one priority for the Rainbow Serpent Festival," Pyrenees Shire Council Mayor Tanya Kehoe said.

"We share the Rainbow Serpent Festival's disappointment that the event could not be held, but are looking forward to working with them on the new-look Rainbow Serpent Festival 2020 and welcoming festival goers back to Lexton later in the year."

Festival organisers have announced plans to hold the 2020 Festival in two stages, with a one-day event in Melbourne on January 26, and a second event at Lexton over Easter.

Festival organisers have also announced plans to assist with the recovery following the fire, with community- related events including tree planting, a working bee, and the delayed opening of the Servo@23 Arts Hub in Beaufort.

"This was a difficult call to make, but it was the correct call based on the current state of emergency in Victoria," Cr Kehoe said.

"We thank Festival organisers for putting patron safety first, and Festival patrons for their patience while this decision was made."
